facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 75 of 1950 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 75 of 1950. Appeal from the Judgment of the High Court

facts.text: Appeal arose from Patna High Court judgment dated 22nd November 1944 in Appeal No. 238 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from the Judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Patna dated 22nd November, 1944, in Appeal No. 238 of 1940 arising out of order dated 13th July, 1940,

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from Subordinate Judge of Bhagalpur order dated 13th July 1940 in Mis. Case No. 174 of 1939.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of order dated 13th July, 1940, of the Subordinate Judge of Bhagalpur in Mis. Case No. 174 of 1939. The facts of the case appear from the judgment.

facts.text: Appeal was transferred from Privy Council to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: DAs J.--This appeal has come up for hearing before us on transfer from the Privy Council. The appellant is the present holder of Taluk Kakwara

facts.text: Appellant is the present holder of Taluk Kakwara which appertains to Mahalat Kharakpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the present holder of Taluk Kakwara which appertains to Mahalat Kharakpur. The respondents represent the Banaili Raj

facts.text: Respondents represent the Banaili Raj which has acquired the Mahalat of Kharakpur.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents represent the Banaili Raj which has also acquired the Mahalat of Kharakpur. The respondents obtained a decree for Rs. 11,587-14-6

facts.text: Respondents obtained a decree for Rs. 11,587-14-6 against the appellant for arrears of rent and cess.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents obtained a decree for Rs. 11,587-14-6 against the appellant for arrears of rent and cess and applied for execution of their decree

facts.text: Respondents applied for execution of decree by attachment and sale of Taluk Kakwara.

anchor.surface_text: and applied for execution of their decree by the attachment and sale of Taluk Kakwara. On August 29, 1939, the appellant judgment-debtor filed an objection

facts.text: On August 29, 1939, appellant filed objection under section 47 CPC alleging Taluk Kakwara was held on Ghatwali tenure and could not be sold in execution of money decree.

anchor.surface_text: On August 29, 1939, the appellant judgment-debtor filed an objection under section 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure alleging that as Taluk Kakwara was held on Ghatwali tenure it could not be sold

facts.text: On May 31, 1940, appellant filed fresh objection under section 47 claiming Taluk Kakwara was held under Government Ghatwali tenure.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of the authorities, the appellant judgment-debtor on May 31, 1940, filed a fresh petition of objection under section 47 of the Code claiming that Taluk Kakwara was held under a Government Ghatwali tenure.

facts.text: Principal question was whether Taluk Kakwara was Government Ghatwali as alleged by appellant or Zamindari Ghatwali as claimed by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The principal question for determination in those execution proceedings was whether Taluk Kakwara was a Government Ghatwali, as alleged by the appellant judgment-debtor, or was a Zamindari Ghatwali held under themselves,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held Taluk Kakwara was Zamindari Ghatwali under Raja of Kharakpur and overruled objection.

anchor.surface_text: as claimed by the Respondents decree-holders. The learned Subordinate Judge held that Taluk Kakwara was a Zamindari Ghatwali under the Raja of Kharakpur and overruled the objection of the judgment-debtor.

facts.text: High Court Bench: Manohar Lal J held Government Ghatwali, inclined to allow appeal; Shearer J held Zamindari Ghatwali, inclined to dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor appealed to the High Court. The appeal came up for hearing in the first instance before a Bench consisting of Manohar Lal and Shearer JJ. Manohar Lal J. came to the conclusion that Taluk Kakwara was a Government Ghatwali

facts.text: Chatterjee J held Taluk Kakwara was Zamindari Ghatwali and dismissed appeal on 22nd November 1944.

anchor.surface_text: and was inclined to allow the appeal. Shearer J. took the view that while Taluk Kakwara was at one time a Government Ghatwali, it ceased to be so and became and remained a Zamindari Ghatwali and as such was alienable and was inclined to dismiss the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Taluk Kakwara was Zamindari Ghatwali tenure alienable with assent of Zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and the circumstances mentioned above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time

facts.text: In 1765 East India Company secured Dewani of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The position of the Zamindars in or about 1765, when the East India Company secured the Dewani of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa, has been described by the Right Honble T. Pemberton Leigh

facts.text: In 1766 Raja Mozaffar Ali, Raja of Mahalat Kharakpur, rose in rebellion against East India Company.

anchor.surface_text: In 1766 Raja Mozaffar Ali rose in rebellion against the East India Company. A strong military force under the command of Captain Browne was sent for quelling the revolt.

facts.text: In 1768 Raja Mozaffar Ali was subdued and imprisoned; East India Company took direct charge of Mahalat Kharakpur.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, in 1768 Raja Mozaffar Ali was subdued and imprisoned. The Raja was deposed and deprived of his estate and the East India Company took direct charge of Mahalat Kharakpur

facts.text: In 1776 Captain Browne granted Sanad (Exhibit 1) for Taluk Kakwara to Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh at fixed jama Rs. 245-12-15 for 22 villages.

anchor.surface_text: and managed it through its officers until the Mahalat was restored to Raja Kadir Ali, the grandson of Raja Mozaffar Ali. In 1776 Captain Browne, who was then in charge of the Mahalat, granted an Amalnama or Sanad (Exhibit 1) in respect of 22 villages

facts.text: Captain Browne's Sanad dated 25th Shanwal 17 corresponding to 7th Pus Bangla 1183 Fasli, described grantees as ghatwals of Taluk Kakwara.

anchor.surface_text: Dated the 25th Shanwal, 17, corresponding to the 7th Pus Bangla, 1183 Fasli. Endorsement. Taluka Kakwara, pargana Danda Sukhwara, appertaining to Kharagpur,

facts.text: In 1780 Mahalat Kharakpur restored to Raja Kadir Ali who was a minor; managed by Mr. Cleveland.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1780 the East India Company restored Mahalat Kharakpur to Kadir Ali, the grandson of the deposed Raja Mozaffar Ali. Although the formal order of the Gover-

facts.text: On January 17, 1780, Raja Kadir Ali granted Sanad (Exhibit 1a) to Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh for Ghatwali tenure of Taluk Kakwara with 177 musketeers.

anchor.surface_text: On January 17, 1780, a fresh Sanad (Exhibit 1 a) was granted in the name and under the Seal of Raja Kadir All to the same two persons, Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh, in the following terms -- Seat of Raja Qadir Ali,

facts.text: Raja Kadir Ali's Sanad specified fixed perpetual quit rent Rs. 245-12-15 inclusive of Zamindari Rasoom for Taluk Kakwara.

anchor.surface_text: Fixed perpetual quit rent 215- 0-15 Rent Zamindari 30-12- 0 Rs. a. d. Rs. a.d. By Bhairo Singh 178- 3- 5 By Rankoo Singh 67-9-10  155-14-15 Rent 59-2- 0 Rent Zamindari 22- 4-10 Zamindari 8-7-10.

facts.text: Taluk Kakwara included in Permanent Settlement of Mahalat Kharakpur in 1793/1796.

anchor.surface_text: In 1789 or 1790 there was a decennial settlement of Mahalat Kharakpur with Raja Kadir Ali which in 1796 was made permanent under the permanent Settlement Regulation I of 1793.

facts.text: 98 Ghatwali tenures including Kakwara listed as appertaining to Kharakpur in government lists of 1860 and 1863.

anchor.surface_text: On February 24, 1860, a list (Exhibit D) of Ghatwali Mahals appertaining to Kharakpur was prepared by the Government showing 98 Ghatwali tenures appertaining to Mahal Kharakpur. Kakwara is item 73 in that list.

anchor.surface_text: Lord Sumner, however, pointed out that it was plain that as the custom depended on proof, and as the tenure in question was one in the Zamindari of Kharakpur and under its Zamindar, it could have no reference to Ghatwali tenures not under him forming part of his Zamindari.

anchor.surface_text: Again, it is well known that at this time 98 of the Ghatwals of Kharakpur took their Sanads from Raja Kadir Ali while only three big Ghatwals, namely, those of Lachmipur, Handwa and Chandan Katoria took their Sanads not from Raja Kadir Ali but from Mr. Dickenson

anchor.surface_text: In 1789 or 1790 there was a decennial settlement of Mahalat Kharakpur with Raja Kadir Ali which in 1796 was made permanent under the permanent Settlement Regulation I of 1793.

arguments.claim: Government lists of 1860 and 1863 include Kakwara as appertaining to Kharakpur

anchor.surface_text: On February 24, 1860, a list (Exhibit D) of Ghatwali Mahals appertaining to Kharakpur was prepared by the Government showing 98 Ghatwali tenures appertaining to Mahal Kharakpur. Kakwara is item 73 in that list.

arguments.claim: Zamindar has right to appoint/dismiss Ghatwals per government letters

anchor.surface_text: Again, the letters from the Collector of Bhagalpur to the Raja of Kakwara written in 1783 and 1808 set out in Lord Kingsdowns judgment in Raja Lelanund Singh v. The Government of Bengal supra clearly show that the Government recognised that the right of appointment and dismissal of a Ghatwal rested with the Raja of Kharakpur.

arguments.claim: Handwa cases analogous to Kakwara

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has relied very strongly on two cases, namely, Narayan Singh v. Niranjan Chakravarti supra and Rani Songbari Kumari v. Raja Kirtyanand Singh 1 . Both the cases related to the Ghatwali of Taluk Handwa.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ng that Taluk Kakwara was a Zamindari Ghatwali. The. principal Sudder Amin having decreed the suit, the defendant appealed. The High Court held that t

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished on facts: sanads different, lists exclude Handwa, paid rasoom etc.

arguments.claim: Taluk Kakwara was in origin Zamindari Ghatwali continued as such alienable with Zamindar consent

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the facts and the circumstances mentioned above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time

holdings.text: Ghatwali tenures held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur were, by custom judicially recognised, alienable with the assent of the Zamindar while Ghatwali tenures like Handwa held under the Government direct were inalienable.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, in Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy which related to the Ghatwali Mahal of Kharna within the Mahalat of Kharakpur the evidence clearly established a number of instances in which there had been unquestioned transfers and sales applicable to Mahals in Kharakpur and it was held by the Privy Council that the true view to take was that such a tenure in Kharakpur was not inalienable, and might be transferred by the Ghatwal or sold in execution of a decree against him, if such transfer or sale was assented to by the Zamindar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and applies Privy Council precedents like Kali Pershad Singh and distinguishes Handwa as independent of Kharakpur Zamindari.

holdings.text: A sale at the instance of the Zamindar in execution of a decree for arrears of rent necessarily implies the existence of such assent.

anchor.surface_text: A sale at the instance of the Zamindar in execution of a decree for ar- rears of rent necessarily implies the existence of such assent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical application of custom requiring zamindar assent to alienability in context of rent decree execution by zamindar.

holdings.text: Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time and further that even if by virtue of Captain Brownes Sanad it became a Government Ghatwali tenure, then under the Sanad of Raja Kadir Ali, or, at any rate, after the Permanent Settlement, Taluk Kakwara became a Zamindari Ghatwali and as such alienable with the consent of the Zamindar according to the custom of Kharakpur judicially recognised.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of historical sanads (Browne and Kadir Ali), inclusion in Permanent Settlement, government lists, and consistent treatment distinguish from Government Ghatwali like Handwa.

holdings.text: The conclusions arrived at by us are in no way inconsistent with the judicial decisions which have been cited before us.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reconciles with prior cases like Raja Lelanund Singh, Munrunjan Singh by noting they treated as Zamindari and distinguished Handwa on facts.

precedents.citation: Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy 1

anchor.surface_text: Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy 1  which related to the Ghatwali Mahal of Kharna within the Mahalat of Kharakpur the evidence clearly established a number of instances in which there had been unquestioned transfers and sales applicable to Mahals in Kharakpur and it was held by the Privy Council that the true view to take was that such a tenure in Kharakpur was number inalienable, and might be transferred by the Ghatwal or sold in execution of a decree against him, if such transfer or sale was assented to by the Zamindar.

precedents.case_name: Kali Pershad Singh v Anund Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: Ghatwali tenure in Kharakpur was not inalienable, and might be transferred by the Ghatwal or sold in execution of a decree against him, if such transfer or sale was assented to by the Zamindar

anchor.surface_text: Narayan Singh v. Niranjan Chakravarti 2  which related to the Ghatwali Mahal of Hand- wa, Lord Sumner recognised that the decision of the Privy Council in the Kharna Ghatwali Mahal case was fully support- ed by the evidence adduced in that case and that that authority had been repeatedly followed and applied in India, and, so far as the reports showed, without proof of the custom being required over again.

precedents.cited_proposition: decision in Kali Pershad Singh fully supported by evidence and repeatedly followed and applied in India without requiring proof of custom over again; but custom of Kharakpur has no application to independent Ghatwali tenures like Handwa

precedents.citation: Raja Lelanund Singh v. Government Ben- gal 1

anchor.surface_text: Raja Lelanund Singh v. Government Ben- gal 1  Many of the greater Zamindars within their respective Zamindaries, were entrusted with rights, and charged with duties, which properly belonged to the Government. They had authority to companylect from the Ryots a certain portion of the gross produce of the lands.

precedents.case_name: Raja Lelanund Singh v Government of Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: position of Zamindars in or about 1765 when East India Company secured Dewani; entrusted with rights and duties of Government including maintaining peace, order, justice, police

precedents.citation: Leelanund Singh v. Thakoor Munranjan Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Leelanund Singh v. Thakoor Munranjan Singh 1  which was a case between the respective predeces- sors of the parties before us and related to this very Taluk Kakwara. Said the learned Chief Justice at p. 255- And it is very necessary for our present purpose to bear in mind what was the true origin and nature of these tenures.

precedents.case_name: Leelanund Singh v Thakoor Munranjan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: true origin and nature of Ghatwali tenures created by Mahomedan Government to provide police and military force to guard mountain passes

anchor.surface_text: Munrunjan Singh v. Raja Lelanund 1  which was also a case between the respective predecessors of the parties before us and related to this very Taluk Kakwa- ra, the High Court at p. 86 observed - It appears that there is companysiderable variety in the tenures known under the general name of Ghatwali in differ- ent parts of the companyntry.

precedents.cited_proposition: considerable variety in Ghatwali tenures; major and minor; some under Zamindar, inferior direct with individuals

precedents.citation: Shib Lal Singh v. Moorad Khan,  1868 9 Suth. W.R. 126.

anchor.surface_text: Shib Lal Singh v. Moorad Khan,  1868 9 Suth. W.R. 126. Then his Lordship pointed out that the superior who appointed the Ghatwal might be the ruling power over the companyntry at large, the landholder responsible by custom for the maintenance of security and order within his estates, or simply the private person, to whom the maintenance of watch- men was, in the case of an extensive property, important enough to require the creation of a regular office.

precedents.case_name: Shib Lal Singh v Moorad Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: personal performance of the ghatwali services is not essential so long as the grantee is responsible for them and procures them to be rendered

precedents.citation: Rani Songbari Kumari v. Raja Kirtya- nand Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Rani Songbari Kumari v. Raja Kirtya- nand Singh 1 . Both the cases related to the Ghatwali of Taluk Handwa. The endeavour of learned companynsel was to show that the Sanad of Captain Browne and the Sanad of Raja Kadir Ali relating to Taluk Kakwara were in their effect the same as the Sanad of Captain Browne and the companyfirmatory Parwang of Mr. Dickenson, the Collector of Bhagalpur, relating to Taluk Handwa.

precedents.case_name: Rani Songbari Kumari v Raja Kirtyanand Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: law relating to Ghatwali tenures (related to Handwa Ghatwali)

precedents.citation: Kali Petshad v. Anund Roy supra

anchor.surface_text: Kali Petshad v. Anund Roy supra , which has been repeatedly followed and applied in India without proof of the custom being required over again.

precedents.case_name: Kali Pershad Singh v Anund Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: custom of alienability of Kharakpur Zamindari Ghatwalis with assent of Zamindar well established and repeatedly followed without re-proof

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the facts and the circumstances numbered above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time and further that even if by virtue of Captain Brownes Sanad it became a Government Ghatwali tenure, then under the Sanad of Raja Kadir Ali, or, at any rate, after the Permanent Settlement, Taluk Kakwara became a Zamindari Ghatwali and as such alienable with the consent of the Zamindar according to the custom of Kharakpur judicially recognised.

outcome.relief_summary: Taluk Kakwara held to be Zamindari Ghatwali tenure, alienable with assent of Zamindar; appellant's objection under section 47 CPC to execution sale overruled

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, in Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy which related to the Ghatwali Mahal of Kharna within the Mahalat of Kharakpur the evidence clearly established a number of instances in which there had been unquestioned transfers and sales applicable to Mahals in Kharakpur and it was held by the Privy Council that the true view to take was that such a tenure in Kharakpur was not inalienable, and might be transferred by the Ghatwal or sold in execution of a decree against him, if such transfer or sale was assented to by the Zamindar.

On a companysideration of the facts and the circumstances numbered above, we are of opinion that Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time and further that even if by virtue of Captain Brownes Sanad it became a Government Ghatwali tenure, then under the Sanad of Raja Kadir Ali, or, at any rate, after the Permanent Settlement, Taluk Kakwara became a Zamindari Ghatwali and as such alienable with the consent of the Zamindar according to the custom of Kharakpur judicially recognised.

edges.explanation: h2 holds sale in execution implies assent, addressing i2's non-sellability due to Ghatwali tenure

anchor.surface_text: A sale at the instance of the Zamindar in execution of a decree for ar- rears of rent necessarily implies the existence of such assent.
